awd_titl_txt: Horizontal Ribbon Growth of Single-Crystal Silicon
awd_abstract_narration:
The manufacture of high efficiency solar cells to convert solar energy to electrical energy currently makes use of a process known as the Czochralski growth process to fabricate high quality silicon wafers. A lower-cost, more efficient manufacturing approach for manufacturing these high quality single-crystal silicon wafers, called horizontal ribbon growth, has been developed. Compared to Czochralski growth, horizontal ribbon growth has the potential to produce thinner and larger wafers at a faster rate and a lower cost, with up to 75% potential cost savings. Commercialization of the horizontal ribbon growth process has been difficult, however, due to a lack of fundamental understanding of the physics that control this process. This award supports research that will contribute new knowledge related to a novel process for manufacturing single-crystal silicon wafers called horizontal ribbon growth. There are currently no models of the process that predict all of the phenomena observed in horizontal ribbon growth experiments. Most importantly, the maximum growth rates attainable have yet to be predicted. The goal of this work is to develop a model of the process that can predict the experimentally observed phenomena including the maximum growth rates. This model will then be used optimize the process so that it can be successfully commercialized. This has the potential to promote the development of new U.S. industries and to bring down the cost of solar energy to the point that solar energy would be cheaper than any other energy source. In addition, this research will contribute to work force training in the areas of fluid mechanics, thermal engineering, and materials science as well as broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in engineering research.

There are currently no models that can accurately predict the horizontal ribbon growth process, and there are many experimental phenomena that occur that are unexplained. Developing a predictive model will give a greater understanding of the process, which will reduce the time and costs needed for commercialization. Because horizontal ribbon growth is not well-understood or studied, there is also an opportunity to make significant fundamental advances in our understanding of solidification kinetics. Studies at molecular to continuum scales will be used to understand and develop predictive models of the processes occurring. This understanding will then be applied to optimize the process and could also lead improvements in other crystal manufacturing processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to develop predictive models of the horizontal ribbon growth process (HRG) and use them to help commercialize the process.  HRG is a technique for producing thin solid sheets of single-crystal silicon for use in solar cells.   Heat is removed from the free surface of a molten pool, which causes the top surface to solidify.  This solid is then pulled horizontally with a specified velocity such that a continuous production process is established. The wafers produced by HRG are single-crystal with low dislocation density and thus would be a drop-in replacement for current wafers, which are produced by the Czochralski process (CZ).  Compared to CZ, HRG has the potential to produce thinner and larger wafers at a faster rate and a lower cost (possibly 75% lower) than CZ.  Commercialization of the HRG process has been difficult, however, because there is a lack of understanding of the solidification physics.  The goal of this work was to develop models of the process that can predict the experimentally observed phenomena including the maximum growth rates attainable by HRG and use the results to guide commercialization efforts.

Intellectual Merit: The technical contributions of this project towards the goal of commercializing HRG include:1. Using molecular dynamics (Image 1), an improved model for and understanding of the 2D nucleation kinetics was developed. It was also shown that the maximum pull speed limits of HRG are highly dependent on the 2D kinetics of solidification and thus HRG experiments can be used to validate 2D kinetic models. (2 journal papers)2. Using singular point analysis techniques, the nature of the temperature field in the vicinity of triple junctions and facet intersection lines was predicted.  2D nucleation occurs at these points so it is important to accurately model them to make reliable predictions of HRG. (2 journal papers)3. Continuum simulations were performed to show that Marangoni and Buoyancy effects combine to create a chaotic unsteady flow in the melt. An image of the unsteady temperature and velocity field caused by this flow is provided (Image 2).   This flow is responsible for two experimentally observed phenomena - ripples on the top surface of the ribbon (Image 3) and thickness variations in the sheet (Image 4).  The thickness variations are a major impediment to commercialization because thin uniform thickness sheets are needed. (1 journal paper)All of these results are currently being used to develop an improved configuration for HRG that avoids flow instabilities and allows high production rates to be achieved.  In addition to the journal papers, the results were also disseminated in 9 conference presentations and 1 invited talk.  These results have impact beyond HRG in that they develop models, analysis techniques, and simulation capabilities that can be applied to all solidification process in particular those involving faceted crystal growth.

Broader Impacts: In addition to helping commercialize HRG, which would reduce the costs of renewable energy and promote job creation in the US, this project has trained one graduate student and two post-doctoral students.  The first post-doc was hired to work by a US-based start-up trying to commercialize HRG.  In addition to the journal papers, conference presentations, and invited talks, the results have also been presented in outreach efforts with undergraduate students to encourage more students to pursue higher degrees in STEM fields. One undergraduate student was recruited to do undergraduate research work on the project and that student has decided to pursue a PhD degree.
